questions.question: The three types of accounting changes are:

options.B: Change in accounting principle, change in estimate, and change in reporting entity
options.C: Prior period, current period, and prospective

questions.explanation: ASC 250 identifies three types of accounting changes: change in accounting principle (different GAAP method), change in accounting estimate (revised expectation), and change in reporting entity (different group of entities).
questions.tip: Three types: principle, estimate, reporting entity.

questions.question: A change in accounting principle is generally accounted for by:

options.B: Retrospective application to all prior periods presented
options.C: Cumulative effect adjustment in current year income
options.D: Restatement only of the most recent prior period

questions.explanation: Changes in accounting principle are generally applied retrospectively—adjusting all prior periods presented as if the new principle had always been used.
questions.tip: Principle change = retrospective (restate prior periods).

questions.question: When applying retrospective treatment for a change in accounting principle, the cumulative effect adjustment is made to:

options.B: Beginning retained earnings of the earliest period presented

questions.explanation: The cumulative effect of the change on periods prior to those presented is reflected in beginning retained earnings of the earliest period presented.
questions.tip: Cumulative effect → beginning retained earnings of earliest period.

questions.question: A change in accounting estimate is accounted for:

options.B: Prospectively, in current and future periods

questions.explanation: Changes in estimate are accounted for prospectively—in the current period and future periods affected by the change. Prior periods are not restated.
questions.tip: Estimate change = prospective (current + future only).

questions.question: Which is an example of a change in accounting estimate?

options.A: Changing from FIFO to LIFO inventory
options.B: Revising the estimated useful life of equipment
options.C: Changing from cash to accrual accounting

questions.explanation: Revising depreciation useful life is a change in estimate. It reflects new information about expected future benefits, not a new accounting method.
questions.tip: Changed useful life, salvage value, bad debt % = estimate changes.

questions.question: Equipment cost $100,000, salvage $10,000, original life 10 years. After 4 years, remaining life is revised to 4 years. What is Year 5 depreciation?
questions.tip: New depreciation = (Current BV - Salvage) ÷ New remaining life.

questions.question: When a change in accounting principle is inseparable from a change in estimate (e.g., changing depreciation methods), it is accounted for as:

options.B: A change in estimate (prospective)

questions.explanation: When a principle change is inseparable from an estimate change, it's treated as a change in estimate—applied prospectively. Examples include changing depreciation methods.
questions.tip: Inseparable principle/estimate = treat as estimate (prospective).

questions.question: A change in reporting entity is accounted for by:

options.B: Retrospective application with restatement of all prior periods

questions.explanation: Changes in reporting entity (like presenting consolidated vs. individual statements) require retrospective application—restating prior period financial statements as if the new entity had always existed.
questions.tip: Reporting entity change = retrospective (restate all periods).

questions.question: Prior period errors, when discovered, are corrected by:

options.B: Restating prior period financial statements

questions.explanation: Prior period errors are corrected by restating the prior period financial statements affected. If comparative statements aren't presented, adjust beginning retained earnings.
questions.tip: Errors = restatement (not a 'change').

questions.question: The key distinction between an error and a change in estimate is:

options.A: Errors are always material; estimate changes are immaterial
options.B: Errors result from mistakes or oversight; estimate changes result from new information
options.C: Errors are always intentional; estimate changes are unintentional

questions.explanation: Errors result from mathematical mistakes, misapplication of GAAP, oversight, or fraud. Estimate changes result from new information or developments causing revision of expectations.
questions.tip: Error = mistake/oversight. Estimate change = new information.

questions.question: An error that affected both Year 1 and Year 2 net income is discovered in Year 3. If comparative statements for Years 1 and 2 are presented, the correction should:

options.A: Adjust only Year 3 beginning retained earnings
options.B: Restate both Year 1 and Year 2 financial statements
options.C: Adjust Year 2 only; Year 1 is too old
options.D: Include the correction in Year 3 income

questions.explanation: When comparative statements are presented, each prior period affected is restated to reflect the correction. Both Year 1 and Year 2 would be restated.
questions.tip: Error: restate all affected periods presented comparatively.

questions.question: An error that counterbalances over two years means:

options.B: If discovered in the third year, no journal entry is needed but prior statements may need restatement
options.C: Both years must always be restated
options.D: The error must be disclosed for 10 years

questions.explanation: Counterbalancing errors (like overstated ending inventory) self-correct over two years. If discovered in year 3+, current balances are correct so no entry is needed, but prior year comparatives may need restatement.
questions.tip: Counterbalancing: self-corrects, but restate comparatives if shown.

questions.question: Year 1 ending inventory was overstated by $20,000. The error was not discovered until Year 3. What is the effect on Year 2 net income?

options.B: Understated by $20,000

questions.explanation: Year 1 ending inventory overstated → Year 1 COGS understated → Year 1 NI overstated. Year 1 EI becomes Year 2 beginning inventory, so Year 2 COGS is overstated → Year 2 NI understated by $20,000.
questions.tip: EI error: opposite effect on next year's NI.

questions.question: Failing to record depreciation is a non-counterbalancing error because:

options.A: Depreciation is not a real expense
options.B: The error does not automatically reverse; assets and retained earnings remain misstated
options.C: Depreciation affects only the balance sheet

questions.explanation: Non-counterbalancing errors don't self-correct. Failure to record depreciation leaves assets and retained earnings misstated until corrected—the error persists indefinitely.
questions.tip: Non-counterbalancing: persists until corrected (e.g., depreciation).

questions.question: When an entity makes a voluntary change in accounting principle, required disclosures include:

options.A: Only the dollar effect on current year
options.B: Nature of change, reasons for change, and effect on prior periods
options.C: Names of board members who approved the change
options.D: No disclosure is required for voluntary changes

questions.explanation: Disclosures for a principle change include: nature of the change, why the new principle is preferable, the method of applying the change, and effects on current and prior periods.
questions.tip: Principle change: disclose nature, reason, and effects.

questions.question: If retrospective application of a principle change is impracticable for all prior periods, the entity should:

options.B: Apply prospectively only
options.C: Apply retrospectively to the earliest period practicable

questions.explanation: If full retrospective application is impracticable, the change is applied retrospectively as far back as practicable. If impracticable for all prior periods, apply prospectively from the earliest date practicable.
questions.tip: Impracticable: go back as far as you can.

questions.question: When a new accounting standard requires a change in principle, the transition method is determined by:

options.B: The specific requirements in the new standard

questions.explanation: New accounting standards often specify the required transition method—which may be retrospective, modified retrospective, prospective, or cumulative effect at adoption date.
questions.tip: New standard = follow that standard's transition guidance.

questions.question: A change from FIFO to weighted-average inventory method is:

options.B: A change in principle (retrospective)

questions.explanation: Changing inventory cost flow methods (FIFO to weighted-average) is a change in accounting principle, requiring retrospective application.
questions.tip: Inventory method change = principle (retrospective).

questions.question: In Year 2, Company discovers it failed to record $50,000 depreciation expense in Year 1. Ignoring taxes, the Year 2 correcting entry includes:

options.B: Debit Retained Earnings $50,000

questions.explanation: The prior period error is corrected by debiting Retained Earnings (reducing it for the missed expense) and crediting Accumulated Depreciation $50,000.
questions.tip: Error correction: debit/credit Retained Earnings, not current expense.

questions.question: When applying retrospective treatment for an accounting principle change, the tax effects are:

options.B: Calculated and included in the retrospective adjustments
options.C: Recognized only in the current year
options.D: Deferred until the change is fully implemented

questions.explanation: Tax effects of accounting changes and error corrections are calculated and included in the retrospective adjustments. Both the pre-tax and tax effects are reflected in restated amounts.
questions.tip: Include tax effects in retrospective adjustments.

questions.question: An immaterial prior period error is typically:

options.B: Corrected in the current period as part of normal operations

questions.explanation: Immaterial prior period errors may be corrected in the current period. Restatement is generally required only for material errors that affect decision-making.
questions.tip: Immaterial errors: correct in current period.

questions.question: When applying retrospective treatment, which effects are included in the adjustment?

options.B: Only direct effects (and related tax effects)
options.D: Neither; only current period is affected

questions.explanation: Retrospective application includes only direct effects of the change (items recorded under the old principle) and related tax effects. Indirect effects (like bonus plan impacts) are recognized in the period of change.
questions.tip: Retrospective = direct effects only. Indirect effects in current period.

questions.question: A change in accounting estimate made in the third quarter of a fiscal year is recognized:

options.A: By restating the first two quarters
options.B: Prospectively from the third quarter forward
options.C: As a cumulative adjustment in the fourth quarter

questions.explanation: Estimate changes are always prospective. If made in Q3, the change affects Q3 and Q4 of the current year and future periods. Prior quarters are not restated.
questions.tip: Interim estimate change: prospective from that quarter.

questions.question: A voluntary change in accounting principle requires that management demonstrate:

options.A: The change will increase net income
options.B: The new principle is preferable in the circumstances
options.D: The old principle was applied incorrectly

questions.explanation: Voluntary principle changes require management to demonstrate the new principle is preferable—that it results in more relevant and reliable financial reporting.
questions.tip: Principle change: must justify why new method is preferable.

questions.question: Which type of accounting matter requires restating prior period financial statements?

options.B: Change in principle and correction of material errors

questions.explanation: Both changes in accounting principle and correction of material prior period errors require restatement of prior periods. Changes in estimate are prospective only.
questions.tip: Restate prior periods: principle changes + error corrections.
